title: Ezra Chapter 9 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezra chapter 9 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezra Chapter 9 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezra Chapter 9.

questions.question: Who came to Ezra to report about the people's actions in Ezra 9:1?
questions.correctAnswer: The princes
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:1 states that the princes came to Ezra to report about the people's actions.

questions.question: According to Ezra 9:2, what sin had the people of Israel committed?
options: They had taken daughters of the peoples of the lands for themselves and their sons
They had refused to build the temple
They had stolen from the priests
questions.correctAnswer: They had taken daughters of the peoples of the lands for themselves and their sons
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:2 explains that the people took daughters from the lands for themselves and their sons, mingling the holy seed.

questions.question: What was Ezra's initial reaction upon hearing the report about the people's transgressions in Ezra 9:3?
options: He rent his garment and mantle and plucked off his hair and beard
questions.correctAnswer: He rent his garment and mantle and plucked off his hair and beard
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:3 describes how Ezra tore his clothes and pulled hair from his head and beard in astonishment.

questions.question: True or False: Ezra sat astonished only until the morning sacrifice according to Ezra 9:4.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:4 says he sat astonished until the evening sacrifice, not the morning.

questions.question: During the evening sacrifice, what posture did Ezra take as he prayed in Ezra 9:5?
options: He fell upon his knees and spread out his hands
He raised his hands and shouted
questions.correctAnswer: He fell upon his knees and spread out his hands
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:5 states that Ezra fell on his knees and spread out his hands to the LORD.

questions.question: What emotion does Ezra express in his prayer in Ezra 9:6?
options: Shame and blush to lift up his face to God
questions.correctAnswer: Shame and blush to lift up his face to God
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:6 records Ezra saying he is ashamed and blushes to lift his face to God.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezra 9:7, the people, their kings, and priests were delivered into the hands of the kings of the lands because of their iniquities.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:7 confirms that their iniquities caused them to be delivered into the hands of foreign kings.

questions.question: What has God given as a sign of grace according to Ezra 9:8?
options: A remnant to escape and a nail in His holy place
questions.correctAnswer: A remnant to escape and a nail in His holy place
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:8 says God showed grace to leave a remnant and give a nail in His holy place.

questions.question: According to Ezra 9:9, what has God done for the people in their bondage?
options: Extended mercy and given reviving to set up the house of God
Sent an army to rescue them
questions.correctAnswer: Extended mercy and given reviving to set up the house of God
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:9 states God extended mercy and gave reviving to rebuild God's house and repair desolations.

questions.question: What question does Ezra ask God in Ezra 9:10 after recounting their sins?
options: What shall we say after this?
questions.correctAnswer: What shall we say after this?
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:10 records Ezra asking, 'And now, O our God, what shall we say after this?'

questions.question: True or False: Ezra 9:11 describes the land they are to possess as clean and holy.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:11 states the land is unclean with filthiness and abominations from the people of the lands.

questions.question: According to Ezra 9:12, what should the people avoid doing to remain strong and inherit the land?
options: Do not give your daughters to their sons or take their daughters to your sons
questions.correctAnswer: Do not give your daughters to their sons or take their daughters to your sons
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:12 instructs not to intermarry with the people of the lands to keep strength and inheritance.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Ezra 9:13: 'And after all that is come upon us for our evil deeds, and for our great trespass, seeing that thou our God hast punished us less than our ______...'
questions.correctAnswer: iniquities deserve
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:13 says God has punished us less than our iniquities deserve.

questions.question: What consequence does Ezra ask God to consider if they break His commandments again according to Ezra 9:14?
options: God's anger until no remnant remains
questions.correctAnswer: God's anger until no remnant remains
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:14 warns God would be angry until they are consumed with no remnant if they break commandments again.

questions.question: How does Ezra describe their current state before God in Ezra 9:15?
options: They remain escaped but cannot stand before God because of trespasses
They are fully forgiven and stand confidently
They have built a great temple
questions.correctAnswer: They remain escaped but cannot stand before God because of trespasses
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:15 states they have escaped but cannot stand before God due to their trespasses.

medium.title: Ezra Chapter 9 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezra Chapter 9 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Ezra 9 teach us about the importance of obedience to God's commands in marriage and family life?
options: Marry only within the holy seed and avoid the peoples of the land
Marry whomever you love regardless of background
Marriage is not important in God's plan
Intermarriage with foreign peoples is encouraged
questions.correctAnswer: Marry only within the holy seed and avoid the peoples of the land
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:1-2 and 9:12 explain that intermarriage with the peoples of the land led to mingling of the holy seed with abominations, and God commanded not to marry their daughters or give daughters to their sons to preserve holiness and strength in the land.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with guilt over sin. Based on Ezra 9, what biblical truth would you share about repentance?
options: Confess your sins humbly and plead for God's mercy
Ignore the sin and hope it goes away
Sin is not serious if you are sorry
questions.correctAnswer: Confess your sins humbly and plead for God's mercy
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:3-6 shows Ezra’s humble confession of sin, tearing his garments and praying with shame, pleading for God's mercy despite great iniquity, teaching the value of honest repentance.

questions.question: What does Ezra 9 teach about God's faithfulness during trials and captivity?
options: God has not forsaken His people despite their bondage
Trials are always punishment without hope
Captivity means God has rejected His people
questions.correctAnswer: God has not forsaken His people despite their bondage
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:8-9 describes God's mercy in giving them a remnant and revival even in captivity, showing His faithfulness and grace during trials.

questions.question: Based on Ezra 9, what is the role of prayer and personal devotion in responding to sin and confession?
options: Prayer is vital to express sorrow and seek God's forgiveness
Prayer is unnecessary when confessing sin
Prayer should only be public, not private
Prayer replaces the need for repentance
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer is vital to express sorrow and seek God's forgiveness
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:5-6 shows Ezra rising from heaviness, kneeling, and spreading out his hands in prayer as part of his confession, emphasizing prayer as a key spiritual discipline.

questions.question: How does Ezra 9 instruct believers to maintain holiness in community life?
options: Avoid alliances and marriages with those practicing abominations
Accept all cultural practices to maintain peace
Ignore sin in community for the sake of unity
Blend all traditions to create harmony
questions.correctAnswer: Avoid alliances and marriages with those practicing abominations
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:11-12 commands no intermarriage or seeking peace or wealth with those whose land is defiled by abominations, teaching separation to maintain holiness.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to compromise their integrity for wealth. What biblical principle from Ezra 9 can you share?
options: Do not seek the peace or wealth of those who practice abominations
questions.correctAnswer: Do not seek the peace or wealth of those who practice abominations
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:12 warns against seeking peace or wealth with the peoples of the land to remain strong and keep God's blessings, highlighting integrity over gain.

questions.question: What does Ezra 9 teach about humility before God in the face of sin?
options: We should be ashamed and confess our iniquities openly
We should boast to hide our sins
Humility is unnecessary if others sin too
Ignore personal sin to avoid shame
questions.correctAnswer: We should be ashamed and confess our iniquities openly
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:6 shows Ezra confessing with shame and blushing to lift his face to God, demonstrating the importance of humility in repentance.

questions.question: True or False: Ezra 9 teaches that God’s anger will not come upon His people if they continue in disobedience.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:14 warns that if the people break God's commandments again and join with abominations, God's anger will consume them until no remnant remains.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezra 9, God’s mercy is extended even when people are in bondage.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:9 states that though they were bondmen, God did not forsake them but extended mercy, giving revival and favor in captivity.

questions.question: How does Ezra 9 emphasize the importance of spiritual revival in difficult times?
options: God gives a little reviving and lightens the eyes even in bondage
Only physical freedom matters, not spiritual
Revival comes from human effort only
questions.correctAnswer: God gives a little reviving and lightens the eyes even in bondage
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:8 mentions God giving a remnant to escape and lightening their eyes for revival during bondage, emphasizing God's power to revive spiritually amid trials.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ezra confessed that their iniquities have grown up unto the ________.
questions.correctAnswer: heavens
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:6 states their trespass is grown up unto the heavens, indicating the enormity of their sins.

questions.question: Based on Ezra 9, how should believers view the consequences of sin in relation to God's justice?
options: God punishes less than we deserve and shows mercy
God always punishes with the full measure immediately
God ignores sin if we are sorry
questions.correctAnswer: God punishes less than we deserve and shows mercy
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:13 shows that God punished them less than their iniquities deserved and gave deliverance, teaching both justice and mercy.

questions.question: What attitude does Ezra 9 suggest believers should have when facing transgressions within the community?
options: Sorrowful and trembling before God's words
questions.correctAnswer: Sorrowful and trembling before God's words
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:4 describes all who trembled at God's words assembling with Ezra, showing humility and sorrow over sin.

questions.question: How does Ezra 9 illustrate the relationship between prayer and perseverance through trials?
options: Prayer sustains believers in heaviness and leads to hopeful action
Trials should be faced without prayer
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer sustains believers in heaviness and leads to hopeful action
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:5 shows Ezra rising from heaviness to pray, demonstrating how prayer helps believers persevere and seek God's help.

questions.question: What biblical principle about leadership responsibility is taught in Ezra 9 regarding sin in the community?
options: Leaders are chiefly responsible for leading the people in obedience
Leaders are not accountable for the people's sins
Leaders should ignore sin to maintain peace
Leaders can encourage compromise with sin
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders are chiefly responsible for leading the people in obedience
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:2 states the hand of princes and rulers was chief in the trespass, highlighting leadership accountability for the people's actions.

hard.title: Ezra Chapter 9 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezra Chapter 9.

questions.question: Which groups of peoples are specifically mentioned as those with whom the Israelites have mingled, leading to the trespass lamented by Ezra?
questions.correctAnswer: Canaanites, Hittites, Perizzites, Jebusites
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:1 lists the peoples: 'Canaanites, the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Jebusites, the Ammonites, the Moabites, the Egyptians, and the Amorites' as those with whom Israel has mingled. This reflects the historical context of Israel's covenantal separation from these nations.

questions.question: What action did Ezra take upon hearing about the intermarriage and mingling of the holy seed with foreign peoples?
options: He rent his garment and mantle and plucked hair
He immediately called a public assembly
He sent messengers to the kings of Persia
questions.correctAnswer: He rent his garment and mantle and plucked hair
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:3 describes Ezra's mourning behavior: 'I rent my garment and my mantle, and plucked off the hair of my head and of my beard, and sat down astonied.' This act reflects traditional Hebrew expressions of grief and repentance.

questions.question: In the prayer of Ezra, what metaphor does he use to describe the growth of Israel's iniquities?
options: Like a mountain reaching the heavens
Like the waves of the sea
Like a fire consuming the forest
questions.correctAnswer: Grown up unto the heavens
questions.explanation: In Ezra 9:6, Ezra says, 'our trespass is grown up unto the heavens,' indicating the enormity and seriousness of their sins from a covenantal perspective, emphasizing the gravity of their disobedience.

questions.question: According to Ezra's prayer, what has God provided to Israel despite their past iniquities and captivity?
options: A remnant to escape and a nail in His holy place
Immediate restoration of the temple and land
A new covenant with a foreign king
questions.correctAnswer: A remnant to escape and a nail in His holy place
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:8 mentions that God has shown grace to leave a remnant to escape and to give a nail in His holy place, symbolizing a secure hold or a point of stability for the people in Jerusalem, which is a theme also developed in prophetic literature like Isaiah.

questions.question: What is the significance of Ezra spreading out his hands to the LORD during the evening sacrifice?
options: It represents a plea for mercy and intercession
It is a sign of surrender to Persian authorities
It is a ritual to initiate the evening sacrifice
questions.correctAnswer: It represents a plea for mercy and intercession
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:5 shows Ezra rising from heaviness, rent his garments, and spread out his hands toward God, a posture of prayer and supplication common in Hebrew worship, indicating an earnest plea for divine forgiveness and restoration.

questions.question: Which historical context is reflected in Ezra’s mention of being delivered into the hands of the kings of the lands?
questions.correctAnswer: Babylonian exile and Persian rule
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:7 references captivity and subjugation 'into the hand of the kings of the lands,' historically reflecting the Babylonian exile and the subsequent Persian rule under which the people of Israel were living during Ezra’s time.

questions.question: True or False: Ezra accuses the princes and rulers of being primarily responsible for the transgression of intermarrying with foreign peoples.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:2 states that 'the hand of the princes and rulers hath been chief in this trespass,' indicating their principal responsibility in leading the people into sin.

questions.question: What does Ezra identify as the consequence of Israel’s iniquities and trespasses throughout their history?
options: Deliverance into the hand of kings to the sword, captivity, spoil, and confusion of face
Prosperity and peace in their land
questions.correctAnswer: Deliverance into the hand of kings to the sword, captivity, spoil, and confusion of face
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:7 describes that due to iniquities, Israel, their kings, and priests have been delivered into the hand of kings to face sword, captivity, spoil, and shame, reflecting the covenantal curses described in Deuteronomy 28.

questions.question: In Ezra's prayer, what does he request regarding marriage alliances with the peoples of the land?
options: Not to give daughters to their sons nor take daughters for their sons
To seek peace and wealth through such alliances
To marry only within the priestly families
To engage in political marriages to strengthen alliances
questions.correctAnswer: Not to give daughters to their sons nor take daughters for their sons
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:12 instructs not to give daughters to their sons nor take daughters for their sons to avoid mingling with the abominable peoples, preserving the covenantal purity as commanded in the Torah.

questions.question: Which literary device is evident in Ezra 9:6, where he says, 'our trespass is grown up unto the heavens'?
options: Hyperbole to emphasize the extent of sin
Simile comparing sin to a tree
questions.correctAnswer: Hyperbole to emphasize the extent of sin
questions.explanation: The phrase 'grown up unto the heavens' is a hyperbolic expression used to emphasize the vastness and seriousness of Israel’s sin, a common literary device in Hebrew poetry and lamentation.

questions.question: How does Ezra’s confession in chapter 9 connect thematically to the covenant renewal themes found in Deuteronomy?
options: By lamenting disobedience and seeking to restore covenant purity
By establishing a new set of laws
By focusing solely on temple rituals
By ignoring past sins and focusing on future prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: By lamenting disobedience and seeking to restore covenant purity
questions.explanation: Ezra 9 reflects the Deuteronomic theme of covenant breach through disobedience and the need for repentance and separation from foreign abominations to restore God’s favor, as emphasized throughout Deuteronomy.

questions.question: The phrase 'a nail in his holy place' in Ezra 9:8 is best understood as a reference to what?
options: A secure hold or point of stability for God's people
A literal nail used in temple construction
questions.correctAnswer: A secure hold or point of stability for God's people
questions.explanation: The 'nail' metaphorically represents a fixed, secure point in God's sanctuary, symbolizing hope and stability amid adversity, a typology connected with God's ongoing presence and covenant faithfulness.

questions.question: What does Ezra express about the justice of God in relation to Israel's survival despite their sins?
options: God is righteous and has allowed a remnant to escape
God has forgotten their sins entirely
God has given them immediate restoration
God is indifferent to their disobedience
questions.correctAnswer: God is righteous and has allowed a remnant to escape
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:15 acknowledges God's righteousness and mercy in preserving a remnant despite their trespasses, reflecting the biblical motif of remnant theology seen in prophetic books like Isaiah and Jeremiah.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the primary authorial intent of Ezra in chapter 9?
options: To confess national sin and call for covenantal repentance
To establish new laws for the people
questions.correctAnswer: To confess national sin and call for covenantal repentance
questions.explanation: Ezra 9 is a penitential prayer highlighting Israel’s failure to maintain holiness through separation, emphasizing confession and repentance as essential for covenant restoration.

questions.question: True or False: Ezra 9 condemns seeking peace or wealth through alliances with foreign peoples as part of the sin committed.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:12 advises not to seek their peace or wealth forever, connecting political and economic alliances with spiritual compromise and covenantal disobedience.

theological.title: Ezra Chapter 9 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezra Chapter 9 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Ezra 9:1, which groups have failed to separate themselves from the abominable peoples of the lands?
options: The people of Israel, priests, and Levites
questions.correctAnswer: The people of Israel, priests, and Levites
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:1 highlights that the people of Israel, including the priests and Levites, did not separate themselves from the peoples of the land, committing abominations. This reflects God's consistent call for holiness and separation from idolatry (Leviticus 20:7-8; Deuteronomy 7:3-4; 2 Corinthians 6:14-17; 1 Peter 1:14-16).

questions.question: What specific sin is described in Ezra 9:2 as having caused the 'holy seed' to mingle with the peoples of the land?
options: Marrying daughters of the peoples of the land
questions.correctAnswer: Marrying daughters of the peoples of the land
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:2 states that the people took daughters of the local peoples for themselves and their sons, causing the holy seed to be mingled. This was against God's command to maintain purity and avoid intermarriage with idolatrous peoples (Deuteronomy 7:3-4; Nehemiah 13:23-27; Joshua 23:12-13; 1 Corinthians 5:6-7).

questions.question: How did Ezra respond upon hearing about the people's sin, according to Ezra 9:3?
options: He rent his garment and mantle and plucked off hair
He immediately called for a fast
He sent a delegation to the king
He ignored the news and continued his work
questions.correctAnswer: He rent his garment and mantle and plucked off hair
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:3 describes Ezra's deep mourning and repentance symbolized by tearing his garments and pulling out hair, a biblical expression of grief and confession (Job 1:20; 2 Samuel 1:11-12; Jeremiah 9:1; Luke 23:48).

questions.question: Who assembled to Ezra because they trembled at the words of the God of Israel, as noted in Ezra 9:4?
options: Everyone who feared God because of the transgressions
questions.correctAnswer: Everyone who feared God because of the transgressions
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:4 states that all who feared the words of God gathered to Ezra due to the people's sin, showing the communal concern for covenant faithfulness (Psalm 34:7; Proverbs 1:7; Acts 9:31; Hebrews 12:28).

questions.question: At what time did Ezra rise from his heaviness and pray, as mentioned in Ezra 9:5?
questions.correctAnswer: At the evening sacrifice
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:5 records Ezra rising at the evening sacrifice to pray, reflecting the biblical practice of worship and intercession at set times (Exodus 29:38-42; Daniel 6:10; Acts 3:1; Psalm 141:2).

questions.question: In Ezra's prayer (Ezra 9:6), what reason does he give for being ashamed and unable to lift his face to God?
options: Iniquities have increased over their head and trespass grown to the heavens
The temple was not yet rebuilt
questions.correctAnswer: Iniquities have increased over their head and trespass grown to the heavens
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:6 expresses deep conviction of sin, stating that their iniquities have multiplied greatly, consistent with biblical themes of confession and repentance (Psalm 38:4; Isaiah 64:5-7; Romans 3:23; 1 John 1:9).

questions.question: What historical consequence does Ezra mention in verse 7 as a result of Israel’s iniquities?
options: Being delivered into the hand of kings for sword, captivity, spoil, and confusion
questions.correctAnswer: Being delivered into the hand of kings for sword, captivity, spoil, and confusion
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:7 recounts past judgments where Israel, their kings, and priests were handed over to enemies, reflecting God's justice in response to sin (2 Chronicles 36:15-17; Jeremiah 25:8-11; Lamentations 5:7; Romans 1:18-32).

questions.question: According to Ezra 9:8, what has God shown to leave a remnant to escape and give a nail in His holy place?
questions.correctAnswer: Grace
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:8 acknowledges God's grace in sparing a remnant and securing a place in the temple, illustrating the biblical doctrine of grace and mercy (Isaiah 10:20-22; Romans 11:5; Ephesians 2:8-9; 2 Timothy 2:19).

questions.question: How does Ezra describe God's mercy in the sight of the kings of Persia in Ezra 9:9?
options: God has extended mercy giving reviving to set up His house and repair it
God has abandoned them to captivity
questions.correctAnswer: God has extended mercy giving reviving to set up His house and repair it
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:9 shows God's mercy allowing restoration of the temple and protection of Jerusalem's walls, consistent with God's faithfulness to His covenant promises (Nehemiah 2:17-18; Psalm 79:8-9; Joel 2:25; Romans 15:8-9).

questions.question: What rhetorical question does Ezra ask God in Ezra 9:10, expressing their guilt?
options: What shall we say after this, for we have forsaken Thy commandments?
Why have you abandoned us forever?
Who can save us from this plight?
questions.correctAnswer: What shall we say after this, for we have forsaken Thy commandments?
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:10 contains a confession of guilt and recognition of having forsaken God's commandments, reflecting biblical calls to repentance (Psalm 32:5; Jeremiah 3:13; Hosea 14:1; 1 John 1:9).

questions.question: According to Ezra 9:11, what has the land become because of the people of the lands and their abominations?
options: An unclean land filled with filthiness and uncleanness
A land flowing with milk and honey
A land of peace and prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: An unclean land filled with filthiness and uncleanness
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:11 describes the land as unclean due to the abominations of the peoples, emphasizing the holiness required of God's people (Leviticus 18:24-30; Numbers 35:33; Ezekiel 36:17-18; 2 Corinthians 6:17).

questions.question: What specific prohibition does Ezra 9:12 give regarding marriage and alliances with the peoples of the land?
options: Do not give your daughters to their sons, nor take their daughters for your sons
questions.correctAnswer: Do not give your daughters to their sons, nor take their daughters for your sons
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:12 instructs avoiding intermarriage with the peoples of the land to maintain covenant purity, consistent with God's commands (Deuteronomy 7:3-4; Nehemiah 13:25; Joshua 23:12-13; Revelation 18:4).

questions.question: In Ezra 9:13, how does Ezra describe God's punishment compared to their iniquities?
options: God has punished less than their iniquities deserve
God has punished exactly as deserved
God has not punished at all
God has punished more than deserved
questions.correctAnswer: God has punished less than their iniquities deserve
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:13 acknowledges God's mercy in punishing less than deserved, teaching about divine long-suffering and grace (Psalm 103:8-10; Lamentations 3:22-23; Romans 2:4; 1 Timothy 1:16).

questions.question: What consequence does Ezra warn of if they break God's commandments again and join with abominable peoples in Ezra 9:14?
options: God's anger until consumption leaving no remnant or escape
questions.correctAnswer: God's anger until consumption leaving no remnant or escape
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:14 warns of severe judgment if they repeat their sins, consistent with biblical warnings about covenant unfaithfulness (Deuteronomy 28:63-64; Ezekiel 9:4-6; Hebrews 10:26-31; Revelation 2:5).

questions.question: How does Ezra describe God in Ezra 9:15 as he confesses their sinful condition?
questions.correctAnswer: Righteous
questions.explanation: Ezra 9:15 declares God as righteous, affirming His just character even as they confess their trespasses, aligning with biblical affirmations of God's holiness and justice (Deuteronomy 32:4; Psalm 7:11; Romans 3:26; Revelation 15:3).
